metadata.title: California Consumer Privacy Act, PII and NLP | by Manu Suryavansh | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: California Consumer Privacy Act, PII and NLP
metadata.description: The California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) or AB 375 came into effect on 1 Jan 2020, it's a State of California law to protect the personal information of California residents among other things…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Coral Edge TPU or NVidia Jetson Nano

all_paragraphs: The California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) or AB 375 came into effect on 1 Jan 2020, it's a State of California law to protect the personal information of California residents among other things. Personally identifiable information (PII) is any data that can be used to identify a user/customer. General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is an EU law passed in 2018 giving similar rights to EU residents. With businesses collecting user data at ever-increasing scale all over the world, I think there will be more such laws passed by different governments everywhere.
CCPA gives the below rights to California residents (taken as-is from here, Section 2) →
In the case of data breaches and other violations, businesses have to pay fines as well.

One of the goals of CCPA is to protect the PII information of consumers and this means companies need to develop tools to understand and store PII information in a safe manner. Natural language processing (NLP) and Natural language Understanding (NLU) technologies are going to play a key role as a significant percentage of data collected is in text form like names, email, addresses, social security numbers, health information etc. The above graphic from Imperva shows various examples of PII. PII can be further sub-divided into PHI (Protected Health Information) data and PCI (Payment Card Industry) data.
NER is the task of identifying things like names, organizations, locations, dates/times etc. NER is can used to identify some of the personal information contained within text data.

So one can train a deep learning model to classify each word in a sentence either as one of the named entities or not. However, there are several libraries which come with pre-trained models for NER task. Identifying the PII information is very important as it can help in fast retrieval of such information, properly securing the information (by encryption etc) and also controlling access to such information. Below are some of the libraries which can be used for NER →

The Stanford core NLP is a popular NLP library written in Java and comes with pre-trained for various NLP tasks like POS (Part of Speech), NER etc for English and several other languages. There is also a newer project StanfordNLP which is a python library which currently supports POS, lemmatization etc but doesn’t support NER.

Spacy is a very popular NLP library with some of the core components written in C which makes it very fast. It also comes with pre-trained models for NER and other tasks for English and several other languages. Spacy has different size models to choose depending on your applications. The models are trained on the OntoNotes 5 dataset. Here I am using the largest English language model — en_core_web_lg (let's look at how to use Spacy for NER →

After recognizing the entities we can mask them (in the above example with ‘xxxx’ to get “My name is xxxx xxxx , I live in xxxx”) to preserve the user’s personal information. Spacy pre-trained models based on Ontonotes 5 can recognize below types of entities →
For information like phone numbers, email etc which spacy cannot recognize regex can be used. Other than masking the PII information can also be encrypted to further protect it.

Presidio is a library from Microsoft specifically developed to protect PII data. It detects the PII data in text (also images) and then it can anonymize the data either by redacting or encrypting it. It actually uses the Spacy NER models by default for detecting certain entities also supports detecting credit card numbers etc. and you can also create custom PII recognizers.

However, the problem comes when we want to recognize entities for a specific domain, for example, if you want to recognize diseases or medicines — in that case, we have to train or fine-tune existing models for custom NER data. For entities which contain only a small list of words, simple look-up may work but still spelling mistakes etc can cause that method to fail! Custom NER models can be trained using Spacy or Flair.

Federated learning — Federated learning is the technique of training a model in a distributed manner while keeping the raw data on individual devices to protect data privacy. For instance, in the case of a mobile phone, the device downloads the existing models and fine-tunes it for the device-specific data so the device data is never shared, all personal training data remains on the devices and the updates are also not shared. This can also be done with Raspberry Pi or other devices. Split Learning is another technique in which models are trained without sharing any raw data, the difference with federated learning is that the model is split and some training can be done at the server. Using edge devices like Coral Edge TPU or NVidia Jetson Nano also help with keeping user data secure.
Differential Privacy — Differential privacy is the technique of sharing a dataset without sharing individual information about the users. From Wikipedia
Various companies like Apple, Google etc use differential privacy techniques to preserve user privacy but also improve the user experience.

Recently there has been a lot of focus on privacy and how to use data for training deep learning models without compromising users privacy. Openmined is an Open Source community whose goal is to make privacy-preserving machine learning easy for everyone. Openmined has developed the PySyft library which supports Federated learning, Differential Privacy and Multi-party Computation, it supports both Pytorch and Tensorflow. OpenMined has also developed PyGrid which is a P2P platform built on top of PySyft to run PySyft in distributed/cloud environment.
CrypTen — It is privacy preserving machine learning framework from Facebook built on top of Pytorch. There is work going on to integrate CrypTen with PySyft.
Tensorflow Privacy — Tensorflow Privacy is an open source library to train ML models with privacy.
Free courses by Udacity and Facebook taught by Andrew Trask (Trask) — Secure and Private AI

With so many data breaches and various companies collecting more and more personal information, there is an increasing need for security and privacy in machine learning, especially in the field of healthcare. With CCPA now active it will be interesting to see its effect on businesses in 2020 and beyond. To learn more about NLP and AI you can follow me on twitter — https://twitter.com/MSuryavansh
